complexity.description: Complexity metrics aim to quantify the readability of a piece of writing by considering various linguistic features, such as sentence length, word length, syllable count or semantic difficulty
ranges: Very easy to read. Easily understood by an 11-year-old student.
Plain English. Easily understood by 13- to 15-year-old students.
Fairly difficult to read. Best understood by high school students
Very difficult to read. Best understood by college students.
Extremely difficult to read. Best understood by university graduates.

formality.description: Formality measures how formal a piece of writing is. It is based on the frequencies of different word classes in the corpus. Nouns, adjectives, articles and prepositions are more frequent in formal styles; pronouns, adverbs, verbs and interjections  are more frequent in informal styles.

sentiment.description: Sentiment aims to determine the attitude of a writer with respect to the overall contextual polarity.

faithfulness.description: Faithfulness measures how broad and accurate are the generated summary using the name entity overlap between the summary and the article. Common named entities include persons, organizations, locations, or dates.
ranges: All or Almost all of the important entities from the article are missing in the generated summary
Very few of the important entities from the article are present in the generated summary
Few of the important entities from the article are missing in the generated summary
All or almost all of the important entities from the article are present in the generated summary

naturalness.description: Naturalness of text is a measure of how well the text flows and sounds like something a native speaker would produce. It shoulb be easy to understand and should adhere to the rules of the language
ranges: Summary is not natural or human-like
summary is somewhat natural and human-like
summary is mostly natural and human-like

length.description: Length measures the number of words in the summary.
